entry.title: Re: Custom field addition in Migration objects Modeler (LTMOM) during S/4HANA Migration.
entry.content:
LTMC (Legacy Transfer Migration Cockpit) as a transaction code/tool used in older SAP S/4HANA releases still technically exists for read/display of existing projects, but its use is deprecated for creating new migration projects.

✳️ The new Fiori-based “Migrate Your Data – Migration Cockpit” has replaced LTMC for actual data migration tasks in modern SAP S/4HANA (Cloud and On-Premise).

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule - Part 2

Introduction

In Part 1, we completed the foundational setup for SAP Joule by:

  • Creating SAP BTP subaccounts and spaces
  • Configuring SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Enabling SAP Build Work Zone
  • Running the Joule Booster to establish system formations

In Part 2, we complete the integration by connecting SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) to SAP Build Work Zone and Joule. This includes:

  • OAuth client creation in SAC
  • Design-time and runtime destination configuration
  • Content provider creation
  • Role consumption
  • User and role provisioning using Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)
  • Final Joule validation

Create OAuth Clients in SAP Analytics Cloud

To allow SAP Build Work Zone and Joule to securely access SAP Analytics Cloud content, OAuth clients must be configured in SAC.

SAP documentation reference:
Consume Role Definition Content from SAP Analytics Cloud

1. Create OAuth Client for Design-Time Access

The design-time OAuth client is used to:

  • Read SAC role definitions
  • Import analytical metadata into SAP Build Work Zone

Procedure

  1. Log in to SAP Analytics Cloud
  2. Navigate to:
    System → Administration → App Integration
  3. Under Configured Clients, choose Add an OAuth Client
  4. Maintain the following values:
    Name: sac-buildworkzone-dt (example)
    Purpose: API Access
    Access: User Provisioning
    Authorization Grant: Client Credentials
  5. Configure Token Lifetime:
    Positive integer value
    Units: minutes, hours, or days
    If not specified, the token lifetime is infinite
  6. Click Add

Save Credentials

  • Copy and store the Client ID
  • Click Copy Secret and save the Client Secret
  • Note the Token Service URL

Important
The client secret is displayed only once and cannot be retrieved later.

OAuth Clients Summary

After completing this step, you should have two OAuth clients in SAP Analytics Cloud:

1. Runtime OAuth Client (Auto-created by Joule Booster)

  • Created automatically during Joule booster execution
  • Used at runtime by Joule
  • Uses SAML Bearer Assertion
  • Client secret cannot be copied

2. Design-Time OAuth Client (Manually Created)

  • Used for:
    Importing SAC roles
    Reading analytical metadata
  • Client ID and secret are used in SAP BTP destinations

Create Design-Time Destination in SAP BTP

This destination enables SAP Build Work Zone to read role definitions from SAP Analytics Cloud.

Procedure

  1. Sign in to the JouleBATTesting subaccount
  2. Navigate to:
    Connectivity → Destinations
  3. Click Create Destination

Destination Configuration

PropertyValue
NameSAC_SWZ_DT
TypeHTTP
URLhttps://<SAC-domain>/api/v1/cdm
Proxy TypeInternet
AuthenticationOAuth2ClientCredentials
Client IDSAC design-time OAuth Client ID
Client SecretSAC design-time OAuth Client Secret
Token Service URL TypeDedicated
Token Service URL Token URL from SAC OAuth configuration

Additional Properties

PropertyValue
HTML5.SetXForwardedHeadersfalse
URL.headers.x-sap-sac-custom-auth true

4. Click Save

Create Runtime Destination by Cloning

Instead of manually creating a runtime destination, reuse the destination created automatically by the Joule booster.

Procedure

  1. Go to:
    Connectivity → Destinations
  2. Locate destination:
    DYN_SAC_SSO
  3. Click Clone
  4. Provide a new name:
    SAC_SWZ_RT

Additional Properties

PropertyValue
sap-card-nominations-path/api/v1/interest-cards
sap-start true
 
5. Save the destination



Assign Required Roles to Users

Before proceeding, ensure the user has required roles.

Procedure

  1. Go to:
    Subaccount → Security → Users
  2. Assign the following roles to the IdP user:
    Launchpad_Admin
    Launchpad_External_User

Create Content Provider in SAP Build Work Zone

This step imports SAC content and role definitions into SAP Build Work Zone.

Procedure

  1. Go to Service Marketplace
  2. Open SAP Build Work Zone
  3. Choose Go to Application
  4. Navigate to Channel Manager
  5. Click + New Content Provider

Content Provider Configuration

PropertyValue
Titlesac.analytics
DescriptionSAP Analytics Cloud content
IDsac.analytics
Design-Time DestinationSAC_SWZ_DT
Runtime DestinationSAC_SWZ_RT
Runtime Destination for Dynamic DataDefault
Automatically add contentEnabled
Use IPS for authorizationsEnabled

6. Click Save

Results

  • SAC role definitions are imported into SAP Build Work Zone
  • System Owner role is intentionally not imported
  • Role changes in SAC require manual refresh from Channel Manager

Provision Users Using Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)

To allow users to access analytical insights via Joule, users, roles, and permissions must be synced from SAC to SAP Build Work Zone.

1. Configure SAP Analytics Cloud as Source System

Reference: SAP Analytics Cloud IPS documentation

Procedure

  1. Open SAP Cloud Identity Services Admin Console
  2. Navigate to:
    Identity Provisioning → Source Systems
  3. Add SAP Analytics Cloud as a source system

Mandatory Properties

PropertyValue
TypeHTTP
URLSAC base URL (no path)
ProxyTypeInternet
AuthenticationBasicAuthentication
UserSAC OAuth Client ID
PasswordSAC OAuth Client Secret
OAuth2TokenServiceURLSAC token service URL
sac.api.version2 (recommended)




2. Configure Transformations

  • Navigate to Transformations
  • Paste the JSON from:
    Default transformation for SAP Analytics Cloud SCIM API v2

3. Configure SAP Build Work Zone as Target System

Reference: SAP Build Work Zone IPS documentation

  • Use the service key JSON from SWZInstanceKey
  • Configure:
    API URL
    OAuth client ID
    OAuth client secret
  • Use default transformation from SAP documentation





Run Provisioning Jobs

Simulate Provisioning

  1. Go to SAC Source System → Jobs
  2. Click Run Now on Simulate Job
  3. Verify logs:
    Identity Provisioning → Provisioning Logs

✔ No errors should appear

Execute Provisioning

  1. Run Read Job
  2. Check provisioning logs again

Validate User Provisioning

  1. Log in to SAP Build Work Zone as Launchpad_Admin
  2. Go to:
    Settings → Identity Provisioning
  3. Enter SAC user email
  4. Validate role IDs are correctly assigned

Create Joule User Role Collection

Procedure

  1. Create User (ex - testuser@test.com)
  2. Go to JouleBATTesting → Security → Role Collections
  3. Create role collection:
    Joule_User
  4. Add:
    Joule roles
    Launchpad_Admin (if site admin access is required)
  5. Assign role collection to IdP users
  6. Log out and log back in









Index Data Using Just Ask and Validate Joule

Reference: SAP Joule documentation

Important Validation Rules

  • SAC models must:
    Belong to the same user
    Be indexed under Just Ask using the same identity
  • Example user:
    testuser@test.com

If models are indexed under a different user, Joule will not return results.





SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule - Part 1

Reference Link
https://help.sap.com/doc/de3af3c0f81642dbaa4d36172ed57a72/CLOUD/en-US/79bfc83ab386450c8cd9c7937ce26a3a.pdf

Thanks
Ashraf

entry.title: Re: Auto extend plant to a material SAP MDG
entry.content:
Hello,

Please make sure to keep the below points into your design consideration -

  • Wrap your code in an update function module with delayed run. 
  • Using Governance API to create a follow up CR is a right approach with additional enhancement of the data but you have to make sure to use the governance API in the right way, for example, locking the main entity, writing the entity data and triggering the workflow using the API.
  • Consider adding an application log for follow up CR creation to log the errors and success messages to ensure that your design is robust and any production issue can be easily checked.
  • Here is the document that you can refer for the technical frameworks of the SAP MDG APIs which will help you writing your code - https://www.sap.com/documents/2015/07/666e4158-5b7c-0010-82c7-eda71af511fa.html

Regards,

Saikat.

entry.title: FREIGHT COST (Planned Delivery costs)
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I have a procurement scenario related to delivery costs with a different freight vendor, and I would appreciate your guidance on how this can be handled in standard SAP.

I created a Purchase Order for 100 quantities with planned delivery costs, where the freight vendor is different from the material supplier.

Process executed:

  1. The first partial Goods Receipt was posted for 50 quantities, followed by:
    • Invoice posting for the material supplier
    • Invoice posting for the freight (delivery cost) supplier
  2. During the second partial delivery for the remaining 50 quantities, the freight supplier and freight charges are different from the first delivery.

Issue faced:

  • There is no option to change the freight vendor or delivery cost values at PO level for the second delivery.
  • When attempting to change the freight vendor during invoice posting, the system throws an error stating that the Invoicing Party is different.
  • This blocks invoice posting for the new freight supplier.

Business concern:
From a business perspective, this is a common scenario in international procurement, where:

  • Each shipment or partial delivery may have a different freight forwarder
  • Freight charges may vary for every delivery

Question:
How can this scenario be handled in a standard SAP way without customization?

  • Is there a recommended process or configuration to manage multiple freight vendors across partial deliveries?
  • What is the SAP best practice for such international procurement scenarios?

Best Regards,

Dinesh U

entry.title: Re: Call derivations on custom event in sap mdg
entry.content:
Hello @VISHAL_JHA , your requirement appears to be a classic application for SAP MDG's enrichment framework. I believe utilizing this framework would be beneficial for your needs, as it is commonly employed in most implementation projects

Should you wish to trigger it consistently, you could consider invoking it within the derivation BADI. However, please be aware that this approach may incur additional costs due to frequent triggering during refresh events. Also note that this can be controlled if you wish to trigger it using a specific button by instantiating CL_FPM and CL_FPM_EVENT to read the current event that triggers while the user clicks the button.

My recommendation would be to trigger the API in a more controlled manner using the SAP MDG's enrichment framework.

Regards

Saikat.

entry.title: How to Access SAP Cloud Logging Service Dashboards Using IAS SAML Authentication
entry.content:
Japanese version

Introduction

SAP Cloud Logging Service (CLS) is an OpenSearch-based observability service that allows you to centrally manage application logs and metrics.

Because CLS Dashboards provide access to application data such as logs and metrics, proper security measures such as authentication methods and access control are essential.

Although CLS Dashboards can be accessed using a Service Key, SAP recommends using SAML authentication with IAS in production environments to ensure proper user management and stronger security.

In this article, we walk through the configuration steps required to enable SAML authentication for CLS Dashboards using IAS.

Prerequisites

This guide assumes the following conditions are met:

  • An IAS tenant is active
  • SAP Cloud Logging Service is available in your SAP BTP subaccount
  • You have administrator privileges for both IAS and the BTP subaccount

Step 1: Create a SAML 2.0 Application in IAS

In the IAS administration application, navigate to Applications & Resources → Applications, and create a new application.

  • Display Name: Any name
  • Protocol Type: SAML 2.0

Step 2: Create a CLS Instance and Configure SAML

If you already have an existing CLS instance, you can update its parameters in the same way as during instance creation.

In this article, we describe the steps using a new CLS instance.

2-1. Create a CLS Instance

Create a CLS instance in your BTP subaccount.

  • Service: Cloud Logging
  • Plan / Runtime Environment: Choose according to your use case
  • Instance Name: Any name

After entering the values, click Next to proceed to the parameter configuration screen.

2-2. Configure SAML Parameters

The default parameters will be displayed. Edit the saml section as shown below.

Default parameters

Updated parameters

{
  "saml": {
    "enabled": true,
    "admin_group": "<IAS_ADMIN_GROUP_NAME>",
    "initiated": true,
    "roles_key": "groups",
    "idp": {
      "metadata_url": "<IAS_TENANT_URL>/saml2/metadata",
      "entity_id": "<IAS_IDP_ENTITY_ID>"
    },
    "sp": {
      "entity_id": "<CLS_SP_ENTITY_ID>"
    }
  }
}

saml section template

Parameter Explanation

admin_group
Users who belong to the specified IAS group are granted administrator privileges (all_access).
In this example, we use cls-admin.

idp.metadata_url
The URL from which CLS retrieves SAML metadata from IAS.
Append /saml2/metadata to your IAS tenant URL.
For example, if your IAS tenant URL is:
https://<YOUR-TENANT-NAME>.accounts400.ondemand.com

then set:
https://<YOUR-TENANT-NAME>.accounts400.ondemand.com/saml2/metadata

idp.entity_id
Open the metadata_url in a browser and set the value of 'entityID' found at the beginning of the XML.

sp.entity_id
The identifier for CLS as a Service Provider. In this example, we use 'CLS-Demo'. The same value must be configured on the IAS side.

Step 3: Configure SAML Settings in IAS

In the IAS application settings, select Configure Manually and configure the SAML settings.

  • Entity ID: Same value as 'sp.entity_id' of the CLS instance

This ID uniquely identifies CLS as the Service Provider in the SAML integration.
Since we used 'CLS-Demo'in the CLS configuration, the same value must be set here.

Endpoint Configuration

  • SSO Endpoint: <Dashboards URL>/_opendistro/_security/saml/acs

  • Single Logout Endpoint: <Dashboards URL>

Verification (Authentication)

Access the CLS Dashboards URL and confirm that authentication succeeds.

At this point, when opening dashboards or index lists, you may see a blank page or permission-related errors.

In Developer Tools, you can also confirm that HTTP 403 (Forbidden) responses are returned.

If you click View roles and identities from the user icon, you will see that only the 'own_index' role is assigned.

This indicates that SAML authentication is working correctly, but authorization (role assignment) has not yet been configured.

Step 4: Configure Attributes in the IAS Application

To use IAS group information for role assignment in CLS, group data must be included in the SAML assertion.

Open Attributes in the IAS application and configure the following:

  • Name: groups
  • Source: Identity Directory
  • Values: All Groups

Step 5: Create a Group and Add Users

Create a user group in IAS with the same name as the 'admin_group' configured in Step 2.
In this example, the group name is 'cls-admin'.

  • Name: Same as 'admin_group'

  • Display Name: Any name

Add the target users to the group.

 

Verification (Authorization)

Access the dashboard page again and confirm that the list of dashboard is now visible.

You can also verify that the 'all_access' role has been assigned to the user via the 'cls_admin' group.


I hope this article helps you with application development and operations on SAP BTP!!

References

  • https://docs.opensearch.org/latest/security/authentication-backends/saml/
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-logging/cloud-logging/prerequisites
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-logging/cloud-logging/configuration-parameters

entry.title: Re: Posting type 4 or 5 in electronic bank statement - ba...
entry.content:
Hi,

 

Account symbols are only evaluated in posting area 1 of transaction OT83.

  • Posting area 1 → determines which G/L account is posted

  • Posting area 2 → used for clearing logic, not for account determination

For posting types 4 and 5 (G/L postings), SAP:

  • Posts the bank clearing account in posting area 1

  • Does NOT automatically copy that account into AVKON / AGKON

  • Leaves FEBEP-AVKON / FEBCL-AGKON empty unless something explicitly fills it

This is by design.

 

Best,

Edrilan Berisha

entry.title: Question: Delivery-cost condition error during Service Entry Sheet
entry.content:
I am using the same PO document type for both material and service POs in SAP S/4HANA.

There is a delivery cost–type condition in the pricing procedure.
It has no condition records, is manual, and is not picking any value automatically from anywhere.

Everything works fine when creating material POs.
However, when I create a Service Entry Sheet for a service PO, the system throws an error related to this condition, even though no value is entered and the condition is not removed.

My questions are:

  • Is this normal behavior for a delivery-cost condition when used with service POs / SES?

  • Does SAP expect delivery cost conditions to be excluded for service scenarios?

  • Or is additional configuration required to prevent this condition from being relevant during SES processing?

I want to understand whether this error is by design or a configuration issue, given that the condition is manual and has no condition records.

entry.title: Re: Track & report reasons for component shortages/spills...
entry.content:
Good day @FaisalMaayeh 

Thank you for your question

To summarise, yes, in public cloud you can capture and report a reason for an additional component issue to a production order. The best way is to use the Reason for Movement on the goods movement type 261 to a production order.

Using the standard analytics for goods movement where Reason for Movement is an available dimension provides you the possibility to report and trend these postings. See Goods Movement Analysis for more details.

Please not that the Reason for Movement field is not always shown for every movement type or in every posting unless you enabled it in your configuration.  See KBA 2865146 and 2596465 for more insights.

Here is a guidance for your tenant:

First, you need to maintain your reason codes list, from which your users can choose. Open your Central Business Configuration or your configuration app. Search for Reason for Movement and maintain your reason codes such as 001 spillage, 002 Damaged during transport, 003 Quantity short at line, etc and save.

Second, you must ensure that you enabled the 261 for the Reason for Movement. If your users receive an error “A reason has to be entered” but cannot see the filed, then your config is correct. See KBA 2865146 and 3697643 for more details.

Third, open Post Goods Movement app that your process uses, post a goods issue with reference to the production order and the component material (movement type 261). In the item details, maintain Reason for Movement with the correct code and post.

Next is to create reports and analytics for trends. For this, you use option A standard analytics. Open Goods Movement Analysis, filter by date range, plant, material and movement type 261.  Add or group by Reason for Movement (which you have maintained during the first step). You can carry out further drilldowns to the material document and production order for more traceability. See Goods Movement Analysis for more details.

Or option B, create a Custom Analytical Query on a material document-based data source.

Include fields such as Production order, material, posting date, movement type, quantity and reason for movement.

Add filters for plant, storage location, production order range and reason code. Then export the result if you need.

Go to Display, Put calendar first in Rows, then Reason for Movement, add any options you need and save.

Then publish, run and export the data.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to Enable Widget Busy Indicator / Ghost Loading indicator for Custom Widgets in SAP Analytics Cl
entry.content:
Hello,

We have created a Bar + Line chart custom widget using Chart.js in SAP Analytics Cloud (Optimized Story Experience).

We want to display the SAC busy indicator whenever the user interacts with the custom widget (for example, on data refresh, filter change, or other interactions).

As per the Custom Widget Developer Guide, custom widgets support viewport loading in the optimized story experience by enabling the following property in the widget JSON:

 

 
"supportsViewportLoading": true

We have enabled this property in our widget JSON. However, when interacting with the widget in view mode, the busy indicator is not shown.

Questions

  1. Is enabling  "supportsViewportLoading": true alone sufficient to trigger the busy indicator?

  2. Do we also need to explicitly fire the customWidgetRenderComplete event, and if so, when exactly should it be fired (after DOM render, after data binding, or after Chart.js rendering)?

  3. Are there any working examples or reference implementations for using viewport loading with custom widgets

  4. If viewport loading does not trigger the busy indicator for interactions, is there any recommended workaround to show a busy indicator for custom widgets?
     

Any guidance or examples would be greatly appreciated.

SAP Analytics Cloud #customwidget #SAC #Chart.js 

#Optimized Story Experience  #JavaScript

@Meet_Patel10    @dishantp40 @Chandra_Bhansali

entry.title: Route Train operation for Inbound processes
entry.content:
With SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing logistics 2310 FPS01 we have enhanced the list of processes which are covered by route train with the following entities:

  • Inbound deliveries
  • Warehouse task without Warehouse request
  • Outbound deliveries for Plant maintenance orders

The following blog will describe the required setup for an inbound delivery-related route train scenario.

Background

Inbound processes are supported with SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing Logistics in 2 ways:

  • Inbound deliveries from Goods receipt from Production
  • Inbound deliveries from external vendors

Inbound deliveries from Production support the putaway of HUs from a production line back to the warehouse while inbound deliveries from external vendors either supply the production itself or can be used to putaway received HUs into the warehouse.

Goods receipt from Production

Production processes need to be set up in advance and we use in this scenario a manufacturing order, which has been created upfront. 

You can e.g. post receipt of HUs based on a manufacturing order. The receipt of Hus can be performed e.g. via RF in SAP EWM with the logical transaction for Receiving of HUs by Manufacturing Order..

You logon to a suitable workcenter and then enter the manufacturing order.

Figure 1: Enter your Manufacturing Order in RF

With the manufacturing order input you need to verify the produced product. When you create an HU, the system automatically creates an inbound delivery for the HU.

Figure 2: Create a new HU in RF 

Figure 3: Created inbound delivery with determined route on item level

This inbound delivery then determines automatically a route based on the condition records, in this scenario we use the destination bin of the HU as decisive criterion for the route determination

The destination bin determination in inbound processes usually happens late in the process-oriented storage control. SAP S/4 HANA for Manufacturing Logistics however needs to determine the destination bin early in the process so that the route train process already knows at the beginning of the document flow where the HU will end up. This information of the final destination for putaway will be determined based on a PPF action /ILO/PDI_01_HU_UPDATE. It determines the destination bin and calls the logistical revaluation to determine the route based on the destination bin. Logistical revaluation then updates the route on inbound delivery item level and HU level.   

After the route has been determined the process for the route train does not differ from the already known loading and unloading process for production supply processes:

Figure 4: Warehouse task with route for inbound delivery

You load your HU and create a tour.

Figure 5: Load HU in RF onto your towing vehicle 

You start the unloading process by departing from the start point

Figure 6: Start unloading process

You unload your HUs at the destination bins and complete your tour.

Figure 7: Unload HU to final destination bin in storage type T040

With this you have loaded HUs from production and brought them back the warehouse for putaway.  More details can be foound on the official help page. 

Goods receipt from external vendors

A similar process exists for inbound deliveries from external vendors. SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing Logistics supports inbound deliveries with a TM scenario using Inbound Cargo registration and inbound deliveries without TM integration. Both processes share the same concept for the route determination: the determination procedure is assigned to the document type and suitable condition records are created.

Inbound deliveries from ICR usually have subHUs in topHUs. The system determines a route for each subHU in the topHU. In case not all determined routes for all subHUs are identical you must manually repack the subHUs which do not fit to the determined route of the remaining HUs. 

For the route train process from external vendors the inbound delivery must be created e.g. manually or via ASN inbound processing. The route determination for an ICR-related delivery starts with the update of the status “ready for warehouse processing”. This triggers as usual the route determination.

The system then creates warehouse tasks for staging and loading. The HUs are loaded onto a tour and are then brought to the PSA or destination bin using the already well-known route train applications in RF.  

One important detail needs to be considered for the demand time calculation: when a HU has a reference to a JIT call and the JIT call has a demand time, then this time is used as the planned arrival time of the tour in case you work with tacted tours. The tour determination then tries to find a suitable tour, which has a end time before the planned demand time at the PSA so that the goods arrive in time at the PSA.

Required configuration

In order to determine a route for inbound deliveries, you need to configure a route determination procedure for your document type of the relevant inbound deliveries.

The stop concept of SAP S/4HANA for manufacturing logistics has been enhanced with release 2023 FPS01. While we supported before this release only PSAs as stops we now also support usual storage bins as destinations. You need to maintain the bins as stops in the Manage Stops app and can then use them in your route for planning and in your condition records for the determination of the route.

entry.title: Re: Advanced integration of other warehouse requests like...
entry.content:
Hello Doreen, 

the PMR-based route trains solution already exists in SAP S/4 HANA for Manufacturing Logistics 2103 and before. You can find some details of the configuration here:  official help page for route determination for 2103 

It is always required for the route train solution that the warehouse request item has a determined route ID. 

In a nutshell: please assign the determination procedure 0ILR01 to your document type for PMR and maintain condition records with the condition type 0IR1. This should solve the route determination issue.

Best regards and sorry for this very late reply

Martin

entry.title: Re: Connection BAS to TRL instance (Abap trial), Cloud Tr...
entry.content:
Hello Alfredo,
 
please don't follow the tutorial https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-custom-ui-bas-connect-s4hc.html for connecting BAS with ABAP trial instance as it is intended specifically for S/4HANA Cloud systems.

To my knowledge the steps in the tutorial https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-environment-deploy-fiori-elements-ui.html should still work for an ABAP trial instance. I tested this briefly with my own trial account and instance:

1. Followed https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-environment-trial-onboarding.html for initial ABAP trial onboarding.
2. Then followed https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-environment-deploy-fiori-elements-ui.html with some minor adjustments:
Step 4.5: I used the SSO Passcode option to ensure I was logged in with my trial account user.
Step 5.4: The destination for default_abap-trial is not created during initial onboarding. You need to create it manually by selecting Cloud Foundry ABAP environment on SAP BTP and then choosing ABAP environment default_abap-trial.

Then it is possible for me to select the system and service successfully.

 



 

From your screenshot, I see an ABAP environment instance named MyNewAbapserver. If there are issues, you could delete its corresponding destination and recreate the destination for default_abap-trial from BAS as described above.
Also, please ensure you are using the same user across your ABAP trial account, ABAP trial instance, and BAS.

Hope this helps!

Best regards,
Peter

entry.title: Re: Wrong Translation in SCT (EN --> KO)
entry.content:
Hi @chulhyuk_choi,

Thank you for your patience while I confirmed this internally.

You are absolutely right. We've verified that the translation of "Material" to "자재" (Raw Material) is an error in the ESG context and needs to be corrected by our development team. We appreciate you for pointing this out with such clarity.

As this is a system-level translation that users cannot change, the correct next step is to create a formal support incident. This will allow us to officially track the issue and assign it to the responsible teams for a fix.

Could you please create an incident via the SAP for Me portal? To ensure it gets routed correctly, please use the following component:

  • Component: SUS-SCT (SAP Sustainability Control Tower)

In the incident description, feel free to link back to this community discussion. This will provide the development team with all the necessary context.

Thank you once again for helping us improve our solution. Please let us know if you have any questions during the incident creation process.

Best regards,
Kauê Da Hora

entry.title: EF Core 9 migrations fail with SAP HANA provider due to missing IMigrationsDatabaseLock support
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We are using SAP HANA Cloud (service type: schema) from an ASP.NET Core application with Entity Framework Core 9 and the Sap.EntityFrameworkCore.Hana provider.

We are facing a blocking issue when using EF Core migrations.

Problem description

When executing migrations (for example, by calling Database.Migrate() during application startup), EF Core throws the following exception:

System.NotSupportedException:
Generating idempotent scripts for migrations is not currently supported for SQLite

The exception occurs in the following method:

IMigrationsDatabaseLock AcquireDatabaseLock()

Important clarification

We were previously using EF Core 6, where migrations worked by generating SQL scripts manually.

The application is correctly connected to SAP HANA Cloud and works properly as long as migrations are not executed.

We are not using SQLite; the error appears to be caused by internal reuse of SQLite migration infrastructure in the HANA provider.

Impact

This makes EF Core migrations unusable with SAP HANA, even when:

  • Using SAP HANA Cloud

  • Using schema-based services

  • Having full DDL permissions

As a result, migrations cannot be applied.

Request / Question

Is there any plan to:

  • Properly implement IMigrationsDatabaseLock for SAP HANA?

  • Remove or replace the SQLite-based fallback in the HANA EF Core provider?

  • Officially support EF Core 9 migrations, even if only partially (as was possible with version 6)?

At the moment, EF Core + HANA can only be safely used as an ORM, not as a schema management tool.

Any guidance, roadmap, or official recommendation would be highly appreciated.

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: SuccessFactors Succession + TaIent Intelligence Hub : Make Skills Decision-Grade
entry.content:
In SuccessFactors Succession, AI-assisted successor recommendations are only as good as the Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) data behind them.

If your Growth Portfolio skills aren’t decision-grade, your successor list won’t be either.

The demo looks magical. Production feels… haunted!!
Because when proficiency is decorative instead of governed, the system can’t separate a “keyword match” from real role readiness, and trust collapses fast.

And that’s when you start seeing it in live tenants: These are real examples, I and my customers experienced during the implementations. 

  • A junior developer appears as a top successor for a VP role because a CV mentioned “strategic planning”.
  • Growth Portfolio turns into a digital junk drawer: everyone is an “Expert” in everything.
  • Managers stop trusting recommendations because they can’t explain why someone was suggested.

The uncomfortable truth:
The AI isn’t the root problem. The skills data is.
More specifically: skills without governed proficiency become decorative proficiency.

When proficiency is treated like profile decoration instead of a controlled data point, AI-assisted matching is forced to guess.

The adoption paradox in Talent Intelligence Hub

Recent TIH capabilities such as resume-based skill extraction (Add from Resume) and AI-assisted skill recommendations/inference reduce the effort to propose and capture skills, which typically increases adoption.

That’s the paradox:

  • Adoption goes up.
  • Signal quality goes down.
  • Trust collapses.
  • Successor suggestions start drifting, because the data becomes noisy.

This is how organizations unintentionally build a “skills-based organization” on top of unverified keywords.

What’s really happening under the hood

AI-assisted recommendations can only be as reliable as the signals you maintain. At minimum, you need clarity on:

  • Skill present (what’s listed)
  • Proficiency level (how strong)
  • Verification / evidence discipline (how do we know)
  • Recency (is it current)
  • Role expectations (what “advanced” means in this role)

When the system has skills but not governed proficiency plus verification discipline, it’s forced to treat too many things as equivalent.

Result: skill inflation produces role-readiness inflation.

The 4-step shift from decoration to data integrity

Before doubling down on AI-assisted successor experiences, four governance questions need clear answers. If these aren’t defined, the system isn’t “smart” -- it’s guessing.

1) Who owns the proficiency scale definition?

Most organizations have “a global scale”. But here’s the trap:

“Advanced” in coding ≠ “Advanced” in sales ≠ “Advanced” in leadership.

If language is standardized but context is ignored, you get inconsistent ratings and inconsistent recommendations.

What to do

  • Assign a true owner: HRIS together with the Talent COE.
  • Define proficiency levels as observable outcomes, not adjectives.

Example outcome-based language

  • Can perform with supervision.
  • Can perform independently.
  • Can coach others / lead complex work.
  • Can define standards / shape strategy.

If it can’t be observed, it can’t be governed.
If it can’t be governed, AI outputs cannot be trusted.

2) Who approves changes (and how is it audited)?

Self-service skills are great for development.
Self-service proficiency that influences succession and other high-stakes talent decisions is risk.

If someone jumps from Level 2 → Level 5 overnight, is that:

  • Growth?
  • Or data tampering (intentional or accidental)?

What to do: create a verification layer for high-impact data.

A practical model that works in real implementations

  • Employees can add skills and self-rate for personal development.
  • For critical skills (succession, key roles, compliance, decision-grade use cases):
    • Require manager verification, peer endorsement, or assessment evidence.
    • Log changes (who, when, what changed, previous vs new).

Outcome: adoption stays high while the signals that matter are protected.

3) What happens when the proficiency scale changes?

This is hidden technical debt in TIH.

If you:

  • move from 5-level → 3-level (to simplify the UI),
  • rename levels, or
  • adjust definitions,

…what happens to years of historical ratings?

Without mapping rules, analytics can show “drops” or “improvements” that are purely structural - not real performance shifts.

What to do: build a simple Change Control Protocol

  • Version scale definitions.
  • Define mapping logic (e.g., old 4–5 → new “Expert”).
  • Communicate changes to managers.
  • Update reporting logic to prevent false trend narratives.

Outcome: People Analytics remains meaningful, and readiness signals stay comparable over time.

4) Can managers explain proficiency in plain language?

Managers avoid rating scales when they feel like grading people.

If the scale is “Level 1–5” with vague labels, the result is often:

  • Inflated ratings
  • Avoidance or random selection
  • Inconsistent adoption across teams

What to do: translate the scale into manager-friendly language

  • Can do this with supervision.
  • Can do this independently.
  • Can coach others.
  • Can lead or design solutions.
  • Can set standards or define strategy.

Then embed this language in:

  • In-app guidance and field help
  • Enablement materials and internal playbooks
  • Manager training with examples anchored in real roles

Outcome: better manager participation, less inflation, higher-quality signals, and stronger recommendations.

What “good” looks like: a simple operating model

For AI-assisted successor recommendations to be credible, three layers must work together.

Layer 1: Adoption (keep it easy)

  • Resume-based extraction and AI-assisted skill recommendations into Growth Portfolio
  • Self-service skill additions
  • Employee-driven development and exploration

Layer 2: Governance (protect the signals)

  • A clearly defined critical skills list (for decision-grade use cases)
  • Verification workflows (manager, peer, or assessment-based)
  • Audit trail and change monitoring for high-impact attributes

Layer 3: Readiness (make it decision-grade)

  • Role expectations aligned to skills and proficiency scales
  • Evidence and recency captured alongside ratings where feasible
  • Reporting that separates signal from noise, not just counts skills

A “Week 1” checklist you can actually use

  • Identify critical roles for succession, leadership, and niche skills.
  • Define critical skills tied to those roles in the Attributes Library.
  • Confirm proficiency scale definitions and rewrite them as observable outcomes.
  • Implement verification for critical-skill proficiency changes.
  • Add audit monitoring (large jumps, frequent changes, spikes by org).
  • Create scale-change mapping and version control conventions.
  • Train managers using plain-language guidance and examples.
  • Build a dashboard that tracks adoption vs verification vs inflation indicators.

The bottom line: AI infrastructure is human infrastructure

As “skills-based organization” moves from buzzword to operating model, success depends less on features and more on data engineering, governance, and change management.

If proficiency is treated like decoration, AI-assisted successor recommendations will remain a toy.
If proficiency is treated as a governed signal, TIH becomes decision-grade and the ROI becomes real.

Over to the community

  1. Are you seeing skill inflation in Growth Portfolio after expanding skill capture (resume-based extraction, inference, self-service)?
  2. How are you governing proficiency credibility without killing adoption?
  3. What verification model works best for you - manager approval, peer endorsement, assessments, or something else?

Conclusion

With the full SuccessFactors suite, you can implement most of what this blog recommends through standard configuration. For the more “advanced” elements, such as monitoring, evidence, and dashboards, you can extend the foundation using People Analytics / SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), Intelligent Services, and reporting. Only a few components are primarily operating-model decisions (governance, ownership, and change control) rather than something you can enable with a single switch in Admin Center. That’s the point: when you treat skills and proficiency as governed signals, Succession recommendations become explainable, defensible, and trusted.

entry.title: Re: Is the SAP BI Platform Support Tool (BIPST) developme...
entry.content:
Hi Roberto, 

The latest release as version 2.1.16 (Patch 16) of the BI Platform Support Tool (BIPST) introduces a key enhancements detailed below:

  • Fully compatible with BI 2025 and BI 4.3+.

  • Upgraded the runtime from Java 8 to SAP JVM 17 for improved security and performance.

  • Added a Java SDK File Analyzer to scan local directories for required dependencies and identify version conflicts.

  • Removed the E2E Trace Wizard, as tracing is now natively integrated into the Fiori BI Launchpad.

  • Deprecated the SAML Configuration Wizard due to new authentication models in BI 2025 and BI 4.3 SP04.

  • Removed legacy utilities including the Screen Recorder, Passport Decoder, and Webi Doc Masker.

  • Cleaned up the Landscape Report by removing deprecated tabs for Explorer and Dashboard components.

  • Fixed a bug where the Change Analysis Page would hang when processing non-standard authentication types.

  • Updated the README with clearer installation steps for both Windows and Linux users.

entry.title: Organización de Servicio y estructura organizativa en S4 HANA Public Edition
entry.content:
Hola  a todos !
Buenos días comunidad, 
 @Javier_del-Peso  quisiera hacerle una consulta a usted y a la comunidad también, si pudieran darnos aportes sobre el caso a continuación

Estamos trabajando en una implementación de una empresa que ofrece servicios profesionales (consultoría, soporte y venta de licencias).

Estamos enfrentando un desafío al momento de querer crear una Organización de servicio (necesaria para crear proyectos de servicios profesionales) y al momento de hacerlo aparece el siguiente mensaje:  "Plant 1100 is not assigned to Purch. Org. 1000 and Sales Org. 1100 "

Según nos han respondido en un caso a SAP, nos indicaron que faltaba asignar al área de ventas el centro. 

En la actividad "Set Up Organizational Structure". Debido a nuestro modelo de negocio, necesitamos vincular varias Áreas de Ventas a un mismo Centro, ya que nuestra sucursal 1 (Centro) es la que presta los servicios para todas las áreas de venta (Sector Público, Privado, etc.).

El problema: Una vez que queremos asignar en el CBC un Centro a un Área de Ventas específica, ese Centro deja de estar disponible en la lista de selección para cualquier otra Área de Ventas. Se aplica una relación N:1 que no nos permite avanzar

Consultas para la comunidad:

  1. ¿Existe alguna forma específica en CBC para permitir la asignación de "Un Centro a Muchas Áreas de Ventas"?

  2. Para quienes trabajan en la industria de servicios: ¿Cómo modelan su estructura cuando un solo punto de entrega (Centro) atiende múltiples canales comerciales (Áreas de Ventas)?

  3. ¿Conocen algún paso adicional para habilitar esta asignación?

Adjunto una imágenes de nuestra estructura (la sociedad X-1000 es la prestadora de Servicios)

 

 

Según se visualiza en esta última imagen se espera poder vincular el mismo centro a distintas áreas de ventas

¡Agradezco de antemano cualquier guía o mejor práctica que puedan compartir!

entry.title: Route Train support process: pickup of HUs after unloading has started
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing Logistics, route trains usually bring goods from the warehouse to destinations (usually production supply areas) in the warehouse where they are e.g. consumed and put into new products.

The supply process can start with a variety of warehouse request document categories like e.g. WMRs for JIT, Kanban with WHR or inbound deliveries. 

We supported up to 2310 FPS01 the additional loading of an HU before the unloading has started. But when the unloading had started it was not possible to add additional HUs onto the tour.

The support of cleanup processes like Clear PSA or on-demand pickup of HUs from PSAs was not supported until SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing Logistics 2310 FPS01.

With this release we support the pickup of HUs on the stops of a route with a variety of process variants:

  • HU with loading warehouse task to endpoint of the route
  • HU without loading warehouse task to endpoint of the route
  • HU with loading warehouse task for putaway beyond endpoint of the route
  • HU without loading warehouse task for putaway beyond endpoint of the route

The HU can either be a structured HU (aka rack) or a usual HU, it can contain products or other HUs or it can be empty.  This gives the users a lot of freedom in the logistics processes. 

Preconditions

The HU which shall be moved back to the warehouse must meet the following requirements:

  • There must be no route assigned to the HU
  • There is no reference document in the HU item available

You can maintain the destination bin e.g. manually in the EWM warehouse monitor under e.g. Documents – Handling Units and then chose the method “Change HU Destination Data”.

If the destination is not part of the current route then the system assumes a multi-step processing from the current bin of the HU to the final bin:

  • movement to the endpoint of the route
  • movement from there with standard EWM routing to the destination.

To achieve the warehouse task to the final destination ,the system determines the way to the endpoint using the putaway strategy to get the correct warehouse process type and possible intermediate steps. 

 

Process description

The operator is on a tour for unloading HUs to stops and unloads HUs. This means that the status of the tour is already “Unloading started”.

After the first HUs have been unloaded the operator can pickup an HU which is at a stop of the current tour.  The operator choses the function code CF1 for Pick up HUs.

Figure 1: Pickup in RF 

The operator enters the HU ID of the picked-up HU. As the HU is not a rack the system requests a destination HU; the operator scans one of the existing racks. The system creates an unloading warehouse task for the picked-up HU to the destination bin of the route.

Figure 2: Pickup in RF: Enter source HU 

Figure 3: Pickup in RF: Enter destination HU 

The operator then continues the unloading process and returns to the endpoint of the route. The confirmation of the endpoint of the route also confirms the unloading warehouse task for the picked-up HU and posts all empties to the endpoint of the route. 

Conclusion

From an operation perspective this scenario can be enhanced with additional warehouse tasks from the endpoint of the route to e.g. an empties buffer or to another staging area or picking process.

It finally gives the users the possibility to have an overview about empty HUs in the supply process; this was not available so far. 

More details can be found here.

entry.title: What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management 2512
entry.content:
As we wrap up 2025, we’ve focused on strengthening core capabilities in SAP Asset Performance Management (APM). This includes transitioning additional applications to the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and enabling embedded analytics for the embedded IoT platform.

Before we dive into the blog, the APM product management team would also like to invite you to join the following webcasts coming up in the New Year:

  • Roadmap Update H1/2026 - SAP Asset Performance Management  Thursday, January 29, 2026 at 4:00 PM Central European Time.
  • What’s New in SAP Asset Performance Management 2602  Weednesday, February 18, 2026 at 4:00 PM Central European Time.

Without further ado, let's check out APM release 2512!

Migration of Risk and Criticality Assessments and Assessment Templates to SAP Cloud Application Programming model (CAP)

SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) is undergoing a significant transition to the SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model. This transition aims to enhance the functionality, scalability, and maintainability of the APM applications.

With this release the Manage Risk & Criticality Assessments and Manage Templates for Risk and Criticality Assessments have transitioned.

Challenge

The original Risk and Criticality Assessments and Assessment Templates had limited flexibility for custom or industry-specific data and did not allow field extensibility to add custom fields,  timeline changes and standard sort and search capability across its list object detail views.
 
The new CAP apps offer the following
  • Improved user experience with more intuitive and efficient management of risk and criticality assessment templates and risk and criticality assessments
  • Possibility to add custom fields via extensibility to enable capturing industry-specific data

For more information, see Asset Risk Assessment on the SAP Help Portal.

New Access Point to new CAP-Based Risk and Criticality apps, plus examples

Find Out More

  • For an introduction into extensibility in APM, read this blog by Archi Garg Extending SAP Asset Performance Management (APM): Three Approaches to Tailoring Your Asset Operations.  
  • For details on how to extend the application, see the SAP Help Portal SaaS Extensibility for Asset Performance Management. and watch this space for a step-by-step video guide - coming soon.
  • For more details on the new CAP-based applications, including required roles, see the SAP Help Portal Asset Risk Assessment. 
  • For more information on release timelines, support, and known limitations, refer to SAP Note 3603407.

 

 

Attribute-Based Access Control Enabled for Alerts

Alerts are now shown only for the technical objects you’re authorized to manage.

Challenge

It was previously not possible to restrict the list of alerts visible to a user based on the technical objects they are responsible for or authorized to manage. As a result, users could see alerts beyond their scope of responsibility, increasing complexity and raising concerns around security and compliance.

Solution

To address this, attribute-based access control (ABAC) has been implemented for alerts. Alert visibility is now determined by attributes of the related technical objects — specifically Maintenance Plant and Planning Plant.

By evaluating these attributes against user authorizations, the system ensures that users can only view alerts associated with technical objects for which they have the appropriate permissions and responsibilities. 

To enable this behavior, the role AccessControlAttributeProvider must be assigned to the user.

Outcome

With attribute-based access control in place, organizations benefit from:

  • Enhanced security and granular access control through restricted alert visibility
  • Support for company-wide rollout, enabling refined access controls across roles and teams
  • Improved compliance, aligning alert access with company policies and regulatory requirements

To sum up, alerts are now delivered to the right users improving focus, accountability, and trust in the system.

For more information, see:

  • Attribute-Based Access Control Role Template
  • Viewing Alerts

Interactive Embedded Analytics Dashboards

The Manage Analytics Dashboard application is now available for the Embedded IoT tenants. It provides interactive charts and tables to visualize data from SAP Asset Performance Management. This helps you analyze and explore the data effectively, leading to valuable insights for improved asset management. For more information, see Manage Analytics Dashboards.

Note that in this release we have only enabled embedded SAC capabilities.

Stay Informed and Get Involved

  • Don't forget to sign up for the upcoming webcasts in January and February 2026 (Roadmap Update H1/2026 - SAP Asset Performance Management and What’s New in SAP Asset Performance Management 2602)
  • You can also explore our latest blog posts here, including topics such as Embedded IoT by @florian_weigold, Industrial Systems by @SonamKinger, and the extensibility blog by @archigarg mentioned earlier.
  • Find out what's up and coming in the SAP Road Map Explorer.
  • For an exhaustive list of all new features, visit the SAP Help Portal - What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management.. 
  • Send us your improvement requests. Submit or vote for the improvement you would like to see in the SAP Continuous Influence session.
  • Check the APM link collection. 

Let us know what you think about these new features - leave us a comment below or ask a question! 

Enjoy the holiday season and see you in the new year for the 2601 update!

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA PMMO Distribution Failure – Project-Valua...
entry.content:
PMMO/GPD only works with Non-Valuated Stock. 

When moving inventory of Non-Valuated Stock it is a quantity only transfer, the Distribution part of GPD is the transfer of the value.  The main use case of PMMO are customers that want Non-Valuated stock so they incur project expenses at GR and not having to wait for GI.

If you want Valuated stock you typically won't need PMMO since material transfers move quantity and value.  With Valuated Stock you can still use Requirements Grouping but you don't need the Distribution.

You can try to increase the run time for Analysis Workbook scheduling on BIP in CMC.  Access the Central Management Console (CMC) in your BusinessObjects with Administrative rights. Navigate to Servers from upper left dropdown, select Service Categories and Core Services /[SIA_NAME].AdaptiveJobServer; One or more of job servers kind is your AdaptiveJobServer with Analysis Office Scheduling Service. entry.title: Re: editable alv report
entry.content:
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report Z_EKPO_EDITABLE_SALV
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Purpose: Display Purchase Order Items (EKPO) with editable columns
*& using CL_SALV_TABLE and modern ABAP 7.5+ syntax
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT z_ekpo_editable_salv.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Type Definitions
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_ekpo,
ebeln TYPE ekpo-ebeln, " Purchase Order Number
ebelp TYPE ekpo-ebelp, " PO Item Number
aedat TYPE ekpo-aedat, " Change Date
txz01 TYPE ekpo-txz01, " Short Text (Editable)
matnr TYPE ekpo-matnr, " Material Number
menge TYPE ekpo-menge, " Quantity (Editable)
netwr TYPE ekpo-netwr, " Net Value (Editable)
END OF ty_ekpo.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Selection Screen
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
SELECT-OPTIONS: s_ebeln FOR ekpo-ebeln.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Global Variables
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
DATA: gt_ekpo TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_ekpo,
go_salv TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table,
go_grid TYPE REF TO cl_gui_alv_grid.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Event Handler Class
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
CLASS lcl_event_handler DEFINITION.
PUBLIC SECTION.
CLASS-METHODS:
" Handle toolbar button events
on_user_command FOR EVENT added_function OF cl_salv_events
IMPORTING e_salv_function,

" Handle data changes in the grid
on_data_changed FOR EVENT data_changed OF cl_gui_alv_grid
IMPORTING er_data_changed.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_event_handler IMPLEMENTATION.

METHOD on_user_command.
CASE e_salv_function.
WHEN 'SAVE'.
" Trigger grid to flush changes to internal table
CALL METHOD go_grid->check_changed_data.

" Here you would implement your save logic
" For standard tables like EKPO, use BAPIs or RAP instead of direct MODIFY
MESSAGE 'Data saved successfully (use BAPI in production)' TYPE 'S'.

WHEN OTHERS.
ENDCASE.
ENDMETHOD.

METHOD on_data_changed.
" This event is triggered when user modifies cells
" You can add custom validations here
DATA(lt_modified) = er_data_changed->mt_good_cells.

LOOP AT lt_modified INTO DATA(ls_mod).
" Add your validation logic here
" Example: Check if quantity is positive
IF ls_mod-fieldname = 'MENGE'.
DATA(lv_value) = CONV menge_d( ls_mod-value ).
IF lv_value <= 0.
" Flag error
er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry(
i_msgid = '00'
i_msgno = '001'
i_msgty = 'E'
i_msgv1 = 'Quantity must be positive'
i_fieldname = ls_mod-fieldname
i_row_id = ls_mod-row_id ).
ENDIF.
ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.
ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* START-OF-SELECTION
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
START-OF-SELECTION.
PERFORM select_data.
PERFORM display_alv.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* FORM select_data
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM select_data.

" Modern inline declaration with host variable escaping (@)
SELECT ebeln, ebelp, aedat, txz01, matnr, menge, netwr
FROM ekpo
WHERE ebeln IN @s_ebeln
INTO TABLE @gt_ekpo
UP TO 100 ROWS.

IF sy-subrc <> 0.
MESSAGE 'No data found' TYPE 'I'.
LEAVE LIST-PROCESSING.
ENDIF.

ENDFORM.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* FORM display_alv
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM display_alv.

TRY.
" Create SALV instance using factory method
cl_salv_table=>factory(
IMPORTING
r_salv_table = go_salv
CHANGING
t_table = gt_ekpo ).

" Configure columns
DATA(lo_columns) = go_salv->get_columns( ).
lo_columns->set_optimize( abap_true ).

" Set column labels
DATA(lo_column) = CAST cl_salv_column_table( lo_columns->get_column( 'EBELN' ) ).
lo_column->set_long_text( 'Purchase Order' ).
lo_column->set_medium_text( 'PO Number' ).
lo_column->set_short_text( 'PO' ).

lo_column = CAST cl_salv_column_table( lo_columns->get_column( 'EBELP' ) ).
lo_column->set_long_text( 'Item Number' ).

lo_column = CAST cl_salv_column_table( lo_columns->get_column( 'TXZ01' ) ).
lo_column->set_long_text( 'Short Text' ).

lo_column = CAST cl_salv_column_table( lo_columns->get_column( 'MENGE' ) ).
lo_column->set_long_text( 'Quantity' ).

lo_column = CAST cl_salv_column_table( lo_columns->get_column( 'NETWR' ) ).
lo_column->set_long_text( 'Net Value' ).

" Enable standard functions (toolbar buttons)
DATA(lo_functions) = go_salv->get_functions( ).
lo_functions->set_all( abap_true ).

" Add custom SAVE button
TRY.
lo_functions->add_function(
name = 'SAVE'
icon = '@2L@'
text = 'Save'
tooltip = 'Save changes'
position = if_salv_c_function_position=>right_of_salv_functions ).
CATCH cx_salv_existing cx_salv_wrong_call.
ENDTRY.

" Register event handler for toolbar buttons
DATA(lo_events) = go_salv->get_event( ).
SET HANDLER lcl_event_handler=>on_user_command FOR lo_events.

" *** ENABLE EDITING - Two approaches depending on your release ***

" Approach 1: For SAP NetWeaver 7.56+ and S/4HANA (Official API)
TRY.
DATA(lo_editable) = go_salv->extended_grid_api( )->editable_restricted( ).

" Make specific columns editable
lo_editable->set_attributes_for_columnname(
columnname = 'TXZ01'
all_cells_input_enabled = abap_true ).

lo_editable->set_attributes_for_columnname(
columnname = 'MENGE'
all_cells_input_enabled = abap_true ).

lo_editable->set_attributes_for_columnname(
columnname = 'NETWR'
all_cells_input_enabled = abap_true ).

CATCH cx_salv_error INTO DATA(lx_error).
" If extended_grid_api is not available, use Approach 2
MESSAGE lx_error->get_text( ) TYPE 'I'.
ENDTRY.

" Approach 2: Access underlying CL_GUI_ALV_GRID (for older releases)
" Uncomment if Approach 1 fails
* DATA: lo_grid_adapter TYPE REF TO cl_salv_gui_table_ida.
* go_grid ?= go_salv->r_controller_r_table->r_model->r_grid.
*
* IF go_grid IS BOUND.
* " Set grid to input-ready mode
* go_grid->set_ready_for_input( 1 ).
*
* " Register data change event
* go_grid->register_edit_event( cl_gui_alv_grid=>mc_evt_modified ).
* SET HANDLER lcl_event_handler=>on_data_changed FOR go_grid.
*
* " Define which columns are editable via field catalog
* go_grid->get_frontend_fieldcatalog( IMPORTING et_fieldcatalog = DATA(lt_fcat) ).
* LOOP AT lt_fcat ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_fcat>).
* CASE <fs_fcat>-fieldname.
* WHEN 'TXZ01' OR 'MENGE' OR 'NETWR'.
* <fs_fcat>-edit = abap_true.
* ENDCASE.
* ENDLOOP.
* go_grid->set_frontend_fieldcatalog( lt_fcat ).
* ENDIF.

" Display the grid
go_salv->display( ).

CATCH cx_salv_msg INTO DATA(lx_msg).
MESSAGE lx_msg->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.

entry.title: Re: message BT175
entry.content:
Hi Ivo.

Message BT175 means "No list exists". Basically, you're trying to view a spool or DME file that was never generated.​

Could you please share the complete F110 log? Also, double-check if the "Create payment medium" checkbox was marked during the run, or try clicking the "Printout/Data medium" button to trigger the file generation.

entry.title: Re: Entendiendo la Extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP: Parte 3
entry.content:
Estimada @monicapimiento 

Me encantan tus tres publicaciones sobre extensibilidad para terminar explicando el valor de BTP.

Me encanta que lo hayas hecho en español porque considero que es mucho más fácil de digerir para nuestros queridos hispanohablantes, mil mil gracias por esto.

Me encanta que te entiendo perfectamente, de hecho, muchos de estos conceptos y argumentos los discuto seguido con Partners y Consultores de SAP Business One, así que esa publicación será mi principal referencia para todos los que buscan entender el beneficio de BTP.

Concuerdo perfectamente en que, si ya tenemos experiencia con BTP y proyectos de SAP Business One, el paso siguiente natural sería escalar esto a proyectos SAP Cloud ERP.

Eres genial y tus publicaciones son muy valiosas, nuevamente mil gracias por regalarnos este conocimiento en español.

Un abrazo,

Erick
